moves.1. d4 d5 2. c4 Bf5: my standard play, against any d4 opening...
moves.3. Nf3 e6: always releasing Bf8, with eyes on square b4: possibly preparing an early c5...
moves.5. g3: what can I say? not what I would have played, but this bloke is way above me...
moves.5... Nf6: at least preparing castling: we have no fear for Qa4+, Nc6, Ne5, Bxc3+...
moves.6. Bg2 Ne4: why not? a free tempo in development for Black: Bb4 is winning in strength and also c5...
moves.7. O-O O-O: the position is fairly equal and balanced here: best White can do, is work on development; in stead, he prefers a tricky trade in the center, to release more pieces...
moves.8. Nxe4 dxe4 9. Nd2: not good: better Nh4; already, Black might consider Qxd4; I thought it was too early: after Nb3, things become unclear...
moves.9... Nc6: bringing another piece in the equation: safest seems e3, or maybe a3...
moves.10. Nxe4: not sure, what to think of this: here is more in the balance for White, than just a pawn trade...
moves.10... Qxd4: however, Black has no second thoughts...
moves.11. a3: compensating for the threat Bxe4, Bxe4, Qxe4, losing a piece...
moves.11... Qxd1 12. Rxd1 Be7: Black has changed the scenery into advantage: White still has to wrap up development, while Black is in full attack mode...
moves.13. Bf4: trying too hard, to finish development: safer was first b4 ; after Bf6, Rb1 or Nxf6+...
moves.14. Bd2: considering Blacks' next move, better Be3...
moves.14... Nd4: posing multiple threats:  the most pregnant being Nxe2+, and then back to square d4; but there is more...
moves.15... Nb3: much stronger, than Nc2: no doubt...
moves.16. Ra2: the final mistake: after Rb1, things would have been different...
moves.16... Rad8: suddenly, all is over: there is no way, to protect Bd2, after Bxe4, so White will lose a piece; he didn't even take the courtesy to resign: he just left the board...
